abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Population and Health Project in
            Jamaica. The main objectives of the project were to: (i)
            achieve the objectives of the National Population Policy
            (1983), namely fertility reduction and the integration of
            population concerns in the public and private sector
            development projects; and (ii) develop a more cost effective
            health services delivery system in line with its Health
            Policy (1984). Bank performance was deficient. Borrower
            performance was deficient. Six key lessons emerge from the
            project and they are as follows: (i) project design must
            reflect the institutional capacity of the implementing
            agency; (ii) to ensure readiness for implementation,
            institutional capacity should be built during preparation;
            (iii)  the practice of placing the responsibility of civil
            works in ministries whose comparative advantage is in other
            areas should be seriously considered; (iv) the complexity of
            government procurement procedures is evident in this project
            and other Bank-financed interventions and requires
            system-wide rather than project-by-project solutions; (v)
            changes in task management during the course of the project,
            particularly one experiencing difficulties, should be
            minimized; (vi) finally, specific project outcome and impact
            measures in addition to input and output indicators should
            be established during design, evaluated as part of the
            project and consistently monitored to determine project
            achievement and impact. To conclude, during the second to
            last year of project implementation, the Bank conducted a
            comprehensive review of the health sector which assessed its
            current status and detailed future options for reforming
            health care provision and financing.

abstracts.cdata!:
The principal objectives of the
            Population and Health Project are to assist the Government:
            (i) to achieve the objectives of the National Population
            Policy (1983) and (ii) to develop a more cost-effective
            health services delivery system in line with its Health
            Policy (1984). To this end, the project consists of three
            parts. Part A seeks to strnegthen population and family
            planning programs through technical assistance and program
            support for: population information in the Population Unit
            of the Planning Institute of Jamaica; family planning
            service delivery in the Ministry of Health (MOH); and
            information education and communication and social marketing
            of contraceptives (CSM) at the National Family Board. Part B
            consists of support for Ministry of Health efforts to
            improve the delivery of an integrated package of services in
            outpatient facilities, strengthen the referral system, and
            support the adoption of a health financing scheme. Finally,
            Part C supports innovative sub-projects designed to improve
            health and family planning programs.
